intro: Castelaria galapagei, commonly known as the Galápagos castelaria, is a flowering plant native to the Galápagos Islands. It belongs to the family Campanulaceae and is characterized by its slender, erect stems and clusters of bell-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments, often in coastal areas or near freshwater sources. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, while its flowers range in color from white to pale blue. Castelaria galapagei plays a significant role in the local ecosystem, providing nectar for pollinators and habitat for small invertebrates.
